results.headline: Mirrors of Love, Unapologetically Yours

results.summary_short: Love is a universe of two in Philippe Garrel’s fatalistic romance “Frontier of Dawn.”

results.summary_short: “New York City Serenade” chronicles a sour, dysfunctional friendship.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Phoebe in Wonderland

results.summary_short: “Phoebe in Wonderland” examines the difference between the growing pains of a gifted child and the possibility of more serious mental illness.

results.headline: Guitars, Whores and Sin: The World of the Fadista

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fados

results.summary_short: “Fados” is Carlos Saura’s big-screen film about the musical genre that is the soul music of Portugal.

results.headline: For a Cold War, a Blue Superhero (and Friends)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Watchmen

results.summary_short: Zack Snyder’s film version of “Watchmen” is a grim and grisly excursion into comic-book mythology.

results.headline: The Heart of a City Dissected by Foreigners

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tokyo!

results.summary_short: “Tokyo!” is a compendium of three surreal shorts whose relationship with one another might best be defined by the exclamation point in the title.

results.headline: Bollywood Fright

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 13B

results.summary_short: “13B” is muted and yellow-hued, as if shot on long-expired film.

results.headline: A Preppy and a Shaggy Dog

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sherman's Way

results.summary_short: Like an annoying new puppy, “Sherman’s Way” just wants to run around in circles and lick your face. After a while, though, you kind of fall in love with it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Explicit Ills

results.summary_short: In “Explicit Ills,” the director, Mark Webber, doesn’t immediately reveal the story’s structure or his intentions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everlasting Moments

results.summary_short: Jan Troell’s “Everlasting Moments” is a film whose title gives a clue about the kind of mood it wants to create.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Beautiful Person

results.summary_short: “La Belle Personne,” directed by Christophe Honoré, combines an earnest respect for literature with a romantic, pop sensibility.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 12

results.summary_short: In “12,” the elements of the modest courtroom classic “12 Angry Men” have been enlarged to operatic dimensions.

results.summary_short: Daddies and daughters lend a wistful emotional core to “Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li,” an otherwise generic martial-arts movie with video-game credentials.

results.summary_short: There are some sharp ideas tucked alongside the tedious high jinks and rank sexism of “Dillinger Is Dead.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jonas Brothers: The 3D Concert Experience

results.summary_short: “Jonas Brothers: The 3D Concert Experience” isn’t a movie so much as a devotional object, a kind of secular fetish designed to induce rapture.

results.summary_short: “Crossing Over” delivers its sanctimony with less hand-wringing and more fist-shaking, complete with lurid violence and periodically bared female flesh.

results.headline: Cerebral Celebrities Entertaining the Big Questions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Examined Life

results.summary_short: Part of the fun of “Examined Life” comes from watching these very intelligent thinkers try to make themselves intelligible.
